did.abstract: Anthony 'Tony' Mazzocchi was an American labor leader. He was an elected official of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union (OCAW), serving as vice president from 1977 to 1988, and as secretary-treasurer from 1988 to 1991. Mazzocchi was an influential organizer for workers' safety, and a significant force behind enactment of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. He was also a co-founder of the Labor Party (U.S.), and was involved in many progressive initiatives of the postwar labor movement, including the civil rights movement, equal pay for women, anti-nuclear proliferation, and Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War. This collection consists of materials created and collected by Tony Mazzocchi documenting his activities as a labor leader, particularly his position as an official of OCAW and his involvement in co-founded the Labor Party (U.S.). The bulk of the materials in this collection document Mazzocchi's efforts to further workers' safety protections, including the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. Materials in this collection include OCAW meeting, election, and convention materials, including agendas, minutes, programs, and proceedings; congressional hearing transcripts concerning healthcare reform and occupational safety; audiovisual recordings; and materials concerning Mazzocchi's memorial service.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Tony Mazzocchi was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders, and described on the collection-level with a box-level inventory. Born-digital items were physical removed from their original locations using a separation sheet, and inventoried but have not yet been forensically imaged, analyzed, or described. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Anthony 'Tony' Mazzocchi (1926-2002) was an American labor leader. He was an elected official of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union (OCAW), serving as vice president from 1977 to 1988, and as secretary-treasurer from 1988 to 1991. Mazzocchi was an influential organizer for workers' safety, and a significant force behind enactment of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970. He was also a co-founder of the Labor Party (U.S.), and was involved in many progressive initiatives of the postwar labor movement, including the civil rights movement, equal pay for women, anti-nuclear proliferation, and Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War. Mazzocchi was a friend and mentor chemical technician and union activist Karen Silkwood; he approved OCAW funds to examine the suspcious circumstances of her death and assisted other workers who had been retaliated against for speaking out against safety and health violations at the Kerr-McGee plant.
